articles.title: Amazon, Microsoft pledge mega AI investments in India
articles.summary: India, which is an emerging AI and cloud infrastructure hub, has witnessed a surge of global tech investment recently.
articles.content:
Amazon, Microsoft pledge mega AI investments in India

Microsoft's Satya Nadella (left) and Amazon founder Jeff Bezos (right) are bullish on India

In October, Google announced a $15bn investment to build an AI data hub, and earlier this week Intel announced a collaboration with Mumbai-based Tata Electronics as its first major customer in the latter's $14bn semiconductor manufacturing plans.

India, which is an emerging AI and cloud infrastructure hub, has witnessed a surge of global tech investments recently.

Amazon said on Wednesday it was pumping in $35bn into India by 2030 to advance AI-driven digitisation, export growth and job creation, a day after Microsoft committed $17.5bn strengthen the country's AI ecosystem.

Tech giants Amazon and Microsoft have announced a combined $52.5bn (£39.4bn) investment plan for India over the coming years.

"When it comes to AI, the world is optimistic about India," Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi said in a post on X, after meeting Microsoft CEO Satya Nadella on Tuesday.

Amazon's $35bn investment will build on the $40bn already invested in India - establishing the company as "the largest foreign investor" in India, the company said in a statement.

A key component of it will go into local cloud and AI infrastructure.

Microsoft's fresh commitment follows a $3bn investment announced by the company earlier this year.

It includes a new "hyperscale cloud region" - a cluster of data centres - in the southern India's Hyderabad city, set to go live in mid-2026, the company said in a statement.

Data centres are centralised physical facilities that host computer servers, IT infrastructure and network equipment, and are a key component of the AI value chain that India is focusing on despite concerns around water shortages.

India will also be given access to Microsoft's "sovereign public cloud", which offers tools to help organisations run their data and applications while keeping sensitive information within the country.

The India investment is part of Microsoft's $23bn AI expansion across countries including Canada, Portugal and the UAE, as the company vies with rivals such as Amazon and Google.

In a statement Microsoft said it also aims to integrate AI into Indian government platforms, supporting around 310 million informal workers.

The announcements come as India steps up activity in semiconductor manufacturing, with several state-backed and private projects aiming to build a domestic chipmaking industry.

While India is a big market for AI - with a billion internet users and a big tech talent pool - it still lags behind global leaders like China and the US.

However, the country has been drawing billions in investments in key computing technologies such as chips, with the government's semiconductor mission offering generous subsidies to firms setting up chip-making facilities.

India's sovereign AI model is also expected to be unveiled in February next year.

Follow BBC News India on Instagram, YouTube, Twitter and Facebook.
articles.reasoning: The article reports significant, large-scale investments by major global tech companies Amazon and Microsoft into India's AI and cloud infrastructure, which will advance digitization, job creation, and technological development in a populous country. The investments have broad societal and economic implications, including infrastructure expansion, government platform integration, and semiconductor industry growth, making it a meaningful and substantive positive development in technology.

Amazon plans to spend $35 billion by 2030 to help create jobs, improve AI technology, and grow exports. Microsoft will invest $17.5 billion, including building a new group of data centers in Hyderabad by 2026, and providing special cloud services for Indian organizations to keep their data secure.

**Impact** – These investments will make India a stronger player in AI and cloud technology. Building data centers and AI infrastructure locally means faster and safer internet services, more tech jobs, and better tools for businesses and government. The deals also support India’s growing semiconductor industry, which makes computer chips needed for AI. This shows that major global companies trust India’s potential in technology.

**What’s next step** – Microsoft and Amazon will start building new facilities and expanding their services in India soon. These moves could attract even more investments and help India compete with tech leaders like the US and China.

**One-sentence takeaway** – Amazon and Microsoft’s huge investments are helping India build strong AI and cloud technology that can create jobs and support future growth.

articles.title: Scientists discover a new state of matter at Earth’s center
articles.summary: New research reveals that Earth’s solid inner core is actually in a superionic state, where carbon atoms flow freely through a solid iron lattice. This unusual behavior makes the core soft, matching seismic observations that have puzzled scientists for decades. The mobility of these light elements may also contribute energy to Earth’s magnetic field. The findings reshape models of Earth’s interior and could apply to other rocky planets.
articles.content:
Beneath Earth's molten outer core is a dense central region -- the inner core, a compact sphere made of an iron and light-element alloy squeezed by more than 3.3 million atmospheres and heated to temperatures comparable to the Sun's surface. For many years, researchers have struggled to explain its unusual behavior. Even though the inner core is solid, it behaves like a softened metal, slowing seismic shear waves and displaying a Poisson's ratio more similar to butter than to steel. This paradox raised a fundamental question: how can the planet's solid center appear firm yet strangely pliable?

A major study published in National Science Review offers a strong explanation. The research team reports that Earth's inner core is not behaving like a conventional solid -- instead, it exists in a superionic state in which light elements move through a stable iron framework as if they were liquid. This finding reshapes our picture of the planet's deepest layer.

The investigation, led by Prof. Youjun Zhang and Dr. Yuqian Huang of Sichuan University, together with Prof. Yu He from the Institute of Geochemistry, Chinese Academy of Sciences, demonstrates that iron-carbon alloys shift into a superionic phase under the inner core's extreme conditions. In this environment, carbon atoms zip through the iron lattice at high speeds, greatly reducing the alloy's stiffness.

"For the first time, we've experimentally shown that iron-carbon alloy under inner core conditions exhibits a remarkedly low shear velocity." said Prof. Zhang. "In this state, carbon atoms become highly mobile, diffusing through the crystalline iron framework like children weaving through a square dance, while the iron itself remains solid and ordered. This so-called "superionic phase" dramatically reduces alloy's rigidity."

Experimental Evidence Confirms Previous Predictions

Although computer simulations in 2022 suggested the inner core might take on this exotic form, confirming it in the laboratory had proven difficult -- until now. Using a dynamic shock compression platform, the researchers propelled iron-carbon samples to 7 kilometers per second, achieving pressures of up to 140 gigapascals and temperatures near 2600 kelvin, closely reproducing the environment found in the inner core.

By pairing in-situ sound velocity measurements with advanced molecular dynamics simulations, the team detected a dramatic loss of shear wave speed and a sharp increase in Poisson's ratio. These results align with the unexpectedly soft seismic characteristics recorded within Earth. On an atomic level, the data showed carbon atoms moving freely through iron's orderly structure, weakening it without causing the lattice to collapse.

A Superionic Core That Shapes Earth's Dynamics

The superionic model not only accounts for long-standing seismic anomalies but also expands our understanding of how the inner core contributes to Earth's internal processes. The motion of light elements may explain seismic anisotropy -- directional variations in seismic wave speeds -- and could also play a role in sustaining Earth's magnetic field.

"Atomic diffusion within the inner core represents a previously overlooked energy source for the geodynamo," said Dr. Huang. "In addition to heat and compositional convection, the fluid-like motion of light elements may help power Earth's magnetic engine."

The study also clarifies debates over the behavior of light elements under extreme pressure. Earlier research focused mainly on compounds or substitutional alloys, but this work highlights the key role of interstitial solid solutions (especially those involving carbon) in controlling the core's physical properties.

A Shift in How Scientists View Earth's Center

According to Prof. Zhang, these findings represent a major change in how scientists interpret the inner core. "We're moving away from a static, rigid model of the inner core toward a dynamic one," he explained.

The implications extend beyond Earth. Identifying a superionic phase in the inner core could also improve our understanding of magnetic and thermal evolution in other rocky planets and exoplanets. As Zhang notes, "Understanding this hidden state of matter brings us one step closer to unlocking the secrets of Earth-like planetary interiors."

This research was supported by the National Natural Science Foundation of China, the Sichuan Science and Technology Program, and the CAS Youth Interdisciplinary Team.
articles.reasoning: The article reports a significant scientific breakthrough in understanding Earth's inner core, confirming a new superionic state of matter that explains seismic anomalies and contributes to Earth's magnetic field. This discovery has broad implications for geophysics and planetary science, reshaping models of Earth's interior and potentially other rocky planets, thus having a meaningful positive impact on scientific knowledge and society's understanding of our planet.
articles.personality_title: Scientists find a new superionic state deep inside Earth’s core
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – Deep inside the Earth lies the inner core, a solid ball made mostly of iron mixed with light elements like carbon. Scientists have long been puzzled because, although it is solid, the inner core behaves more like a soft metal than a hard one, which didn’t match what they expected.

**What happened** – A team of researchers from China used powerful experiments to recreate the extreme pressure and heat found in the inner core. They discovered that the inner core is in a special state called "superionic," where carbon atoms move freely like a liquid inside a solid iron structure. This movement makes the inner core softer and explains strange seismic wave patterns observed for decades.

**Impact** – This discovery helps solve a big mystery about Earth’s center and changes how scientists think about its inside. The moving carbon atoms may also help power Earth’s magnetic field, which protects life from harmful space radiation. Plus, this new understanding could help explain the cores of other rocky planets beyond Earth.

**What’s next step** – Scientists will now study how this superionic state affects other Earth processes, like magnetic activity and heat flow. They may also explore if planets like Mars or exoplanets have similar inner cores, which could change what we know about planet formation and behavior.

**One-sentence takeaway** – Scientists have discovered that Earth’s inner core is a superionic state where carbon atoms flow inside solid iron, explaining its soft behavior and influencing the planet’s magnetic field.
articles.personality_title_fr: Les scientifiques découvrent un nouvel état superionique au cœur de la Terre
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – Au centre de la Terre se trouve le noyau interne, une boule solide composée principalement de fer et de petits éléments comme le carbone. Les scientifiques étaient intrigués car, bien que solide, ce noyau interne se comporte comme un métal mou plutôt que dur, ce qui ne correspondait pas à leurs attentes.

**Ce qui s’est passé** – Une équipe de chercheurs chinois a recréé en laboratoire la pression et la chaleur extrêmes du noyau interne. Ils ont découvert que ce noyau est dans un état spécial appelé « superionique », où les atomes de carbone circulent librement à l’intérieur d’une structure solide de fer. Ce mouvement assouplit le noyau et explique des anomalies dans les ondes sismiques observées depuis des décennies.

**Impact** – Cette découverte résout un grand mystère sur le centre de la Terre et change la vision scientifique de ses profondeurs. Les atomes de carbone mobiles pourraient aussi contribuer au champ magnétique terrestre, qui protège la vie des radiations spatiales. De plus, cette nouvelle compréhension pourrait éclairer le fonctionnement des noyaux d’autres planètes rocheuses.

**Prochaines étapes** – Les scientifiques vont étudier comment cet état superionique influence d’autres processus terrestres, comme l’activité magnétique et le transfert de chaleur. Ils chercheront aussi si des planètes comme Mars ou des exoplanètes possèdent un noyau similaire, ce qui pourrait modifier nos connaissances sur la formation et le comportement des planètes.

**Résumé en une phrase** – Les scientifiques ont découvert que le noyau interne de la Terre est dans un état superionique où les atomes de carbone circulent dans un fer solide, ce qui explique sa douceur et influence le champ magnétique de la planète.
articles.personality_title_es: Científicos descubren un nuevo estado superiónico en el centro de la Tierra
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – En el centro de la Tierra está el núcleo interno, una esfera sólida hecha principalmente de hierro y elementos ligeros como el carbono. Los científicos estaban confundidos porque, aunque es sólido, el núcleo interno actúa más como un metal blando que duro, algo inesperado.

**Qué pasó** – Un equipo de investigadores en China recreó en el laboratorio la presión y temperatura extremas del núcleo interno. Descubrieron que el núcleo está en un estado especial llamado "superiónico", donde los átomos de carbono se mueven libremente dentro de una estructura sólida de hierro. Este movimiento hace que el núcleo sea más blando y explica patrones extraños en las ondas sísmicas observadas durante décadas.

**Impacto** – Este hallazgo resuelve un gran misterio sobre el centro de la Tierra y cambia cómo los científicos entienden su interior. Los átomos de carbono móviles podrían también ayudar a mantener el campo magnético de la Tierra, que protege la vida de la radiación espacial. Además, esta comprensión podría ayudar a explicar los núcleos de otros planetas rocosos.

**Próximos pasos** – Los científicos estudiarán cómo este estado superiónico afecta otros procesos en la Tierra, como la actividad magnética y el flujo de calor. También explorarán si planetas como Marte o exoplanetas tienen núcleos similares, lo que podría cambiar lo que sabemos sobre la formación y el comportamiento de los planetas.

**Resumen en una frase** – Los científicos descubrieron que el núcleo interno de la Tierra está en un estado superiónico donde los átomos de carbono fluyen dentro del hierro sólido, explicando su comportamiento blando e influyendo en el campo magnético del planeta.

articles.title: Digital Poland is an example for digital Europe
articles.summary: Elektroniczne Zarządzanie Dokumentacją is a system that all public entities can use free of charge.
articles.content:
Changes in digital Poland are a good example of how digital Europe should change, said on Monday Deputy Prime Minister, Minister of Digital Affairs Krzysztof Gawkowski. The more offices in the digital system, the easier the cooperation between public administration units, he added.

Deputy Prime Minister Krzysztof Gawkowski, during the conference “Dissemination of EZD – digital transformation in administration,” emphasized that the Electronic Document Management system (EZD RP) is one of the foundations of the state’s digital transformation.

“Changes in digital Poland are a good example of how digital Europe should change. Poland’s digital transformation is today one of the best examples in the entire European Union. Electronic Document Management is the type of system format where not only office employees, not only the administration, but above all citizens have a sense of closeness to the administration,” said Gawkowski.

He noted that Poland has spent billions on transforming Polish administration into a digital one. “Today, millions are being used to transform it into a digital, digitized, open one. This is over 200 million zlotys from the National Recovery Plan and 30 million zlotys from the funds of the Ministry of Digital Affairs,” he added.

“The more offices in the system, the easier the cooperation between public administration units, but also between citizens. Digitalization is a new way of thinking about how the state will change before our eyes,” he added.

Electronic Document Management is a system that all public entities, including offices, can use free of charge. As stated on its website by the Ministry of Digital Affairs, one of the benefits resulting from the implementation of Electronic Document Management in administration is the transparency of institutional operations. “Thanks to reflecting in the IT system all activities performed by officials in the course of handling cases, clients of the administration have the opportunity to become acquainted with the way their case is handled,” explains the Ministry.

The Electronic Document Management system is being developed by the Ministry of Digital Affairs and NASK, using funds from the National Recovery Plan. The Central IT Center (COI) is responsible for the system from the technical side. (8.12.2025)
articles.reasoning: The article describes a significant digital transformation in Poland's public administration through the implementation of a free Electronic Document Management system (EZD RP). This system improves transparency, efficiency, and cooperation between public entities and citizens, representing a meaningful technological advancement with broad societal benefits. The story includes sufficient context and details about funding, implementation, and impact, making it a substantive example of positive digital innovation with wide public significance.

Deputy Prime Minister Krzysztof Gawkowski spoke on December 8, 2025, explaining that this system helps offices work together better and makes it easier for citizens to follow their cases.

**Impact** – This system is important because it improves how government offices share information and serve people. Citizens can see how their cases are handled, which makes the process more open and trustworthy. Poland has invested a lot of money—over 230 million zlotys—from national recovery funds to build and improve this system.

**What’s next step** – The government will continue developing EZD RP with help from the Ministry of Digital Affairs, the NASK research center, and the Central IT Center. They aim to include more offices and improve the system’s technology, making public services even more accessible and efficient.

**One-sentence takeaway** – Poland’s free digital document system is a key step in making government work clearer, faster, and easier for both offices and citizens.

articles.title: The Swiss city that lets you pay for most things with bitcoin
articles.summary: Shops, restaurants and even the local council in Lugano now accept the cryptocurrency.
articles.content:
The Swiss city that lets you pay for most things with bitcoin

4 hours ago Share Save John Laurenson Business reporter, Lugano, Switzerland Share Save

AFP via Getty Images Shops and restaurants across the Swiss city of Lugano now accept bitcoin

In a McDonald's by a lake surrounded by mountains, in the centre of the Swiss city of Lugano, a customer orders coffee. "Can I pay with bitcoin?" he asks, and the person behind the counter holds out what looks like a credit card payment terminal. It is in fact a machine for paying by crypto currency. The equipment has been distributed free to local retail businesses by the city council. The buyer pays by contactless, from the bitcoin wallet on his mobile phone. The bill comes to 0.00008629, which is roughly $8.80 (£6.60). Few people who have bought bitcoin would probably think about using it to purchase actual things in shops. It is instead generally seen as an investment, a bet on its value going up. But in Lugano, in the Italian-speaking part of Switzerland, it's a different story.

While you can of course still pay for everything in Swiss francs, some 350 shops and restaurants now also accept bitcoin. The local authority has even started taking payments in crypto currency for municipal services. You can, for example, pay for pre-school childcare in bitcoin. I get talking to the McDonald's customer, Nicolas, who comes from France. He is what you might call a bitcoin true believer. "What's great about paying in bitcoin is the feeling of freedom it gives you," he says. "You are no longer dependant on a financial system with its middlemen and its costs." Nicolas says he's discovered bitcoin cards in Switzerland. These are prepaid gift cards. You buy a certain sum in Swiss francs but download it in bitcoin onto a digital wallet on your phone. I walk through the centre of Lugano, down a high street where just about all the shops sell luxury stuff. Jewellery or expensive clothes mainly. In a shop called Vintage Nassa that sells new and second-hand bags and watches, the owner Cherubino Fry tells me he accepts bitcoin because the processing fee he has to pay per transaction is less than those charged by credit card companies. For bitcoin it is generally below 1%, while for debit cards it can be as high as 1.7%, and up to 3.4% for credit cards. Although for the latter two it can vary from country to country. I ask Mr Fry if he does much business in bitcoin. "In reality, not a lot. For now, only sporadically, only some clients," he says. "But using bitcoin will be like a tree growing, and this tree will grow very big in five, 10 years."

Users pay via bitcoin using a suitable app on their mobile phone

A stone's throw from Mr Fry's shop, I visit the headquarters of Plan B, an initiative launched in 2022 by the City of Lugano in collaboration with crypto currency platform Tether. With the B standing for bitcoin, its stated aim is to educate people about cryptocurrency, and "to make Lugano the European hub for bitcoin". "I want to talk about an experiment I did this July," says Plan B hub director Mir Liponi. She explains that she had a problem with her bank, which resulted in her not being able to access her funds. For 11 days she had no way of paying, other than with bitcoin, but she says that experiment turned out well, and that you can mostly survive just on bitcoin in Lugano. "It's missing public transportation at the moment… another one is fuel. Groceries are okay. I got things delivered at home, even. "Plenty of medical places, but not a dentist. And another big thing is [energy] bills. You cannot pay bills in bitcoin yet." Ms Liponi adds that in the future she wants to see "circular economies where people earn bitcoin, keep bitcoin, spend bitcoin, pay for services in bitcoin".

Yet elsewhere, similar bitcoin projects to Lugano's have come unstuck. In 2021, El Salvador made bitcoin legal tender alongside the US dollar. To encourage its use the government gave people the bitcoin equivalent of $30 that they downloaded via an app. "So what people did was download the app, exchange the bitcoin for dollars and never use it again," says Vincent Charles, head of crypto currency firm Unchain Data. He went to El Salvador earlier this year to see how bitcoin uptake was going, and concluded that people don't really use it, and retailers and service providers rarely accept it. However, there are other successful bitcoin adoption examples from around the globe. Slovenian capital Ljubljana was declared the world's most crypto-friendly city in a report back in April, followed by Hong Kong and Zurich.

Shopkeeper Cherubino Fry expects the use of bitcoin to grow strongly

Back in Lugano, not everyone is seemingly impressed with bitcoin. In a park on the lakefront there used to be a statue representing Satoshi Nakamoto, the pseudonym used by the unknown person or persons who claim to have invented the crypto currency back in 2008. In August, vandals broke the sculpture into bits and threw it into Lake Lugano. "It's interesting because not that many things get vandalised around here," says Lucia, a passerby who lives in the city. "People are usually fairly well behaved. And you don't see often people having very strong political opinions either." She adds, though, that she herself is skeptical of cryptocurrencies in general. "At the University of Lugano where I study there's a club to promote bitcoin and everything. I do find it surprising that institutions such as my university would promote cryptocurrencies so much. I think they are associated with crime, with the dark web and speculation. "A lot of people lose their money because they invest in a cryptocurrency and then it crashes."
